Source: Purpose: To determine predictors of best-corrected postoperative visual acuity (VA) in patients who underwent surgical intervention for macula-off rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.
Output: Goal: To identify factors that can predict how well patients' eyesight will be after surgery for a particular type of retinal detachment.

Source: Materials and methods: Primary macula-off retinal detachments from the University of Colorado Primary Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment Database (2012-2017) were reviewed.
Output: Materials and methods: We looked at data from patients with a specific type of retinal detachment who were treated at the University of Colorado between 2012 and 2017. The size of the detachment, the condition of the macula, and the patients' eyesight before surgery were all important factors in determining how well they could see six months after surgery. By looking at certain factors before surgery, doctors can give patients a better idea of how well their eyesight will be after the operation.

Source: The primary outcome measure was a postoperative VA of 20/40 or better at least 6 months after surgery.
Output: The main goal was to see if patients had at least 20/40 vision or better six months after surgery.

Source: Patient demographics, medical history, duration of central vision loss before surgery, examination findings, operative technique, and postoperative findings were analyzed as possible predictors of postoperative visual recovery to 20/40 or better.
Output: We looked at patient information like age, medical history, how long they had vision loss, and the results of their eye exams, surgery, and recovery to see if these factors could predict if they would have 20/40 vision or better after surgery.

Source: Chi-square or Fisher's exact test was used to compare categorical variables, and Wilcoxon rank sum test was used for continuous variables.
Output: We used statistical tests to compare different types of information, like whether patients had certain characteristics or if they had different results from their eye exams, surgeries, and recoveries.

Source: A multivariable logistic regression analysis was used to determine the adjusted odds ratios and 95% confidence intervals for variables that were significant in the univariable analyses.
Output: We calculated the odds ratios and confidence intervals for factors that were found to be important in our analysis.

Source: Statistical significance was set at p < 0.05.
Output: We considered results to be statistically significant if the probability of them occurring by chance was less than 5%.

Source: Results: One hundred thirty-one patients met inclusion criteria.
Output: Results: 131 patients were included in the study.

Source: Eighty-one (61.8%) patients achieved a postoperative VA of 20/40 or better 6 or more months after surgery.
Output: Results: 81 out of 131 patients (about 62%) had vision of 20/40 or better six months after surgery.

Source: Patients with a single retinal break were more likely than patients with more than one break to reach a postoperative VA of 20/40 or better (76.9% vs. 55.4%, p = 0.021).
Output: Patients who had only one retinal break were more likely to have 20/40 vision or better after surgery compared to patients who had more than one break (76.9% vs. 55.4%, with a p-value of 0.021).

Source: Patients with a better preoperative logMAR VA had better postoperative VA (p = 0.021).
Output: Patients who had better eyesight before surgery were more likely to have better eyesight after surgery (p = 0.021).

Source: Duration of central vision loss prior to surgical repair was not related to final postoperative VA in this particular study.
Output: The length of time a patient experienced vision loss before surgery did not affect their eyesight after surgery in this study.

Source: Conclusion: Postoperative recovery of visual acuity to 20/40 or better was significantly more common in patients with a single retinal break as well as in patients with better preoperative visual acuity.
Output: In conclusion, patients who had only one retinal break and better eyesight before surgery were more likely to have good eyesight after their operation.

Source: Duration of central vision loss prior to surgical repair was not significantly associated with postoperative VA.
Output: The amount of time a patient experienced vision loss before surgery did not have a significant impact on their eyesight after the operation.

Source: Objective: To assess the effect on hemostasis parameters of a new combined oral contraceptive (COC).
Output: Goal: To determine how a new birth control pill affects blood clotting.

Source: Study design: In this randomized, single centre, open-label, exploratory study, healthy women received either 15 mg estetrol/3 mg drospirenone (E4/DRSP) (n = 39), 30 mcg ethinylestradiol/150 mcg levonorgestrel (EE/LNG) (n = 30), or 20 mcg ethinylestradiol/3 mg drospirenone (EE/DRSP) (n = 32) for six 28-day cycles.
Output: Study Design: In this study, healthy women were randomly assigned to receive either a new birth control pill containing 15 mg estetrol and 3 mg drospirenone, a commonly used birth control pill containing 30 mcg ethinylestradiol and 150 mcg levonorgestrel, or another commonly used birth control pill containing 20 mcg ethinylestradiol and 3 mg drospirenone. They took the pills for six cycles, each lasting 28 days.

Source: Blood was collected at baseline, cycle 3, and cycle 6.
Output: Blood samples were collected at the beginning of the study and at the third and sixth cycles.

Output: Results: At the end of the study, the average increase in blood clotting was 30% for women taking the new birth control pill, 165% for women taking the commonly used birth control pill, and 219% for women taking another commonly used birth control pill. Source: Changes to prothrombin fragment 1 + 2 and SHBG for E4/DRSP, EE/LNG, and EE/DRSP were +23%, +71%, and +64% (p-value <0.05 vs E4/DRSP); and +55%, +74% and +251% (p-value <0.05 vs E4/DRSP), respectively.

Source: At cycle 6, changes to other hemostasis parameters for E4/DRSP were similar or smaller than for EE/LNG or EE/DRSP.
Output: By the sixth cycle of the study, the changes in other blood clotting parameters were similar or smaller in women taking the new birth control pill compared to the other commonly used birth control pills.

Source: Conclusions: In this study, changes in hemostasis parameters after treatment with 6 cycles of E4/DRSP were smaller or similar to those observed for EE/LNG.
Output: Conclusions: This study found that the new birth control pill had similar or smaller effects on blood clotting compared to the commonly used birth control pill.

Source: Similar, but more pronounced changes were also observed versus EE/DRSP, which supports the hypothesis that the effect of COCs on hemostasis parameters is mainly mediated by the estrogenic component.
Output: Similar, but stronger changes were also seen compared to the other commonly used birth control pill, which suggests that the estrogen in birth control pills is the main factor affecting blood clotting.

Source: Further studies are needed to provide more insight into the venous thromboembolic risk of E4/DRSP.
Output: More studies are needed to understand the risk of blood clots with the new birth control pill.

Source: Implications statement: This study reports that the effects on hemostasis parameters of a COC containing 15 mg E4/3 mg DRSP are less or similar to those for EE/LNG or EE/DRSP.

Source: It also demonstrates that the choice of estrogen modulates the effects of COCs on hemostasis parameters.

Source: Importance: There is considerable public and scientific debate as to whether screen use helps or hinders early child development, particularly the development of language skills.
Output: Why is this important: Many people and scientists are discussing and researching whether using screens helps or harms the development of young children, especially their language skills.

Source: Objective: To examine via meta-analyses the associations between quantity (duration of screen time and background television), quality (educational programming and co-viewing), and onset of screen use and children's language skills.
Output: Goal: The aim of this research is to look at different factors (such as how much time children spend using screens, the type of programs they watch, and whether adults watch with them) and see how they are related to children's language skills.

Source: Data sources: Searches were conducted in MEDLINE, Embase, and PsycINFO in March 2019.
Output: Where the data came from: In March 2019, searches were performed in three databases: MEDLINE, Embase, and PsycINFO.

Source: The search strategy included a publication date limit from 1960 through March 2019.
Output: What the search focused on: The search for articles included publications from 1960 up until March 2019.

Source: Study selection: Inclusion criteria were a measure of screen use; a measure of language skills; and statistical data that could be transformed into an effect size.
Output: Which studies were chosen: Studies were included if they measured both screen use and language skills, and provided data that could be analyzed to determine the impact.

Source: Exclusion criteria were qualitative studies; child age older than 12 years; and language assessment preverbal.
Output: Which studies were not chosen: Studies that focused on qualitative research methods, children older than 12 years, or language assessments before children were able to speak were not included.

Source: Data extraction and synthesis: The following variables were extracted: effect size, child age and sex, screen measure type, study publication year, and study design.
Output: How the data was analyzed: The researchers collected information on several factors, including the impact size, age and gender of the children, how screen time was measured, when the study was published, and the type of study design used.

Source: All studies were independently coded by 2 coders and conducted in accordance with the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses guidelines.
Output: How the studies were analyzed: Two coders individually reviewed and coded all of the studies, following the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses guidelines.

Source: Main outcomes and measures: Based on a priori study criteria, quantity of screen use included duration of screen time and background television, quality of screen use included co-viewing and exposure to educational programs, and onset of screen use was defined as the age children first began viewing screens.
Output: What the researchers measured: The researchers looked at how much time children spent using screens, whether adults watched with them, the type of programs they watched, and at what age they started using screens.

Source: The child language outcome included assessments of receptive and/or expressive language.
Output: What the researchers measured for language skills: The researchers looked at how well children understood and/or expressed language.

Source: Results: Participants totaled 18 905 from 42 studies included.
Output: What the results showed: The study included a total of 18,905 participants from 42 different studies.

Source: Effect sizes were measured as correlations (r).
Output: How the effect sizes were measured: The researchers used correlations (r) to measure the impact.

Source: Greater quantity of screen use (hours per use) was associated with lower language skills (screen time [n = 38; r = -0.14; 95% CI, -0.18 to -0.10]; background television [n = 5; r = -0.19; 95% CI, -0.33 to -0.05]), while better-quality screen use (educational programs [n = 13; r = 0.13; 95% CI, 0.02-0.24]; co-viewing [n = 12; r = 0.16; 95% CI, 0.07-.24]) were associated with stronger child language skills.
Output: What the results showed: Spending more time using screens (measured in hours per use) was linked to lower language skills, while watching educational programs and watching screens with an adult were associated with stronger language skills in children.

Source: Later age at screen use onset was also associated with stronger child language skills [n = 4; r = 0.17; 95% CI, 0.07-0.27].
Output: What the results showed: Starting to use screens at a later age was linked to stronger language skills in children.

Source: Conclusions and relevance: The findings of this meta-analysis support pediatric recommendations to limit children's duration of screen exposure, to select high-quality programming, and to co-view when possible.
Output: What this means: The results of this study support the advice from pediatricians to limit the amount of time children spend using screens, choose high-quality programs, and watch screens together with an adult whenever possible.
